message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of chronic lymphedema and the appearance of the lesion suggest Lymphangiosarcoma. Cellulitis would have localized redness, warmth, and tenderness. Lichen planus would have pruritic polygonal papules. Kaposi sarcoma would have violaceous macules or nodules.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The chronic lymphedema and the color and appearance of the plaques suggest lymphangiosarcoma. Kaposi sarcoma can also present with purple plaques but it is usually seen in immunocompromised patients. Cellulitis would not present with plaques or ulceration. Lichen planus typically presents with papules or small vesicles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of chronic lymphedema, which puts her at risk for lymphangiosarcoma. The presentation of purple-colored plaques with associated ulceration is consistent with this diagnosis. Cellulitis would have more redness and inflammation, while lichen planus and Kaposi sarcoma do not typically present in this manner.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s chronic lymphedema and the appearance of the lesions suggest lymphangiosarcoma. Cellulitis would present with erythema and tenderness. Lichen planus would not present with ulceration. Kaposi sarcoma is typically associated with immunosuppression and would typically present with lesions on the lower extremities or mucous membranes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of chronic lymphedema and the appearance of the lesion suggest lymphangiosarcoma. Cellulitis would present with erythema and warmth rather than just purple discoloration. Lichen planus and Kaposi sarcoma would not typically present with the ulceration seen in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history of chronic lymphedema and the appearance of the purple-colored plaques with ulceration suggest lymphangiosarcoma. Cellulitis does not typically present with coalescing purple-colored plaques, while lichen planus and Kaposi sarcoma are less likely diagnoses in this patient population.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The long-standing history of lymphedema in the right arm is a risk factor for lymphangiosarcoma, which is a rare tumor that develops in chronically lymphedematous areas. The appearance of the lesion is also consistent with lymphangiosarcoma. The other options are unlikely given the patient’s history and presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of chronic lymphedema, which increases the risk of developing lymphangiosarcoma. The purple, heterogeneous plaques with ulceration are consistent with lymphangiosarcoma. Cellulitis would be more likely to cause warmth and tenderness rather than plaques. Lichen planus typically presents with pruritic, flat-topped, violaceous papules. Kaposi sarcoma is associated with immunosuppression, which is not mentioned as a factor in this patient's history.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history of chronic lymphedema after radical mastectomy, along with the heterogeneous, purple-colored plaques with associated ulceration, strongly suggest lymphangiosarcoma. Cellulitis typically presents with erythema, warmth, and tenderness, while lichen planus and Kaposi sarcoma do not typically present with ulceration.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has chronic lymphedema of the right upper extremity since mastectomy, and skin exam shows heterogeneous, purple-colored plaques with associated ulceration. These symptoms suggest lymphangiosarcoma, which is a rare malignant tumor of endothelial cells lining lymphatic vessels. All other options are less likely given the patient’s history and symptoms.
